docs.lead_paragraph: New I.R.S. rules that went into effect this year, as part of the Affordable Care Act, made it harder for consumers to have non-prescription medicines reimbursed from health-care flexible spending accounts. To be reimbursed for over-the-counter medicines, consumers now must obtain a prescription for the items-even though a prescription isn't required to buy them in the first place.
docs.snippet: New I.R.S. rules that went into effect this year, as part of the Affordable Care Act, made it harder for consumers to have non-prescription medicines reimbursed from health-care flexible spending accounts.     To be reimbursed for over-the-counter...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some 10 million Americans have osteoporosis, and 34 million more with low bone mass are at risk of developing this silent disease.

headline.seo: A Reminder on Bone Health and Osteoporosis
headline.main: A Reminder on Maintaining Bone Health
headline.print_headline: A Reminder on Maintaining Bone Health

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column analyzes benefits and risks of drug treatments for osteoporosis.
docs.snippet: Some 10 million Americans have osteoporosis, and 34 million more with low bone mass are at risk of developing this silent disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

headline.seo: Python Digestion Study Holds Promise for Human Heart Health
headline.main: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs
headline.print_headline: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Science finds that a combination of fatty acids allows heart cells of a well-fed python to expand while snake digests its prey; study, conducted by scientists at the University of Colorado, holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.
docs.snippet: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

byline.contributor: Maria Elkin contributed reporting from Washington.
